questions.question:
Question 1: A 20 year old male presents with acute onset cough and thick sticky sputum. There is a 
history of repeated lung infections since childhood. Chest Xray shows evidence of bilateral 
upper lobe bronchiectasis. On evaluation, the chloride concentration in his sweat is >60 
mEq/L. What is the organism majorly associated with this patient's respiratory disease?
questions.explanation:
Bilateral upper lobe bronchiectasis with a history of repeated lung infections since childhood and 
evelated sweat chloride concentration suggests a diagnosis of cystic fibrosis (CF). Pseudomonas 
aeruginosa is a common etiological agent associated with chronic airway infection in patients 
with cystic fibrosis (CF). 242 
Sold by @itachibot In cystic fibrosis, there is thick inspissated mucus and impaired mucociliary clearance. Due to 
these factors, lungs are often colonized in infancy and early childhood with Staphylococcus aureus 
and Haemophilus influenzae. In adulthood, they are replaced by P. aeruginosa. This results in 
chronic inflammation, which leads to airway modelling and bronchiectasis. Note: Burkholderia cepacia complex is an opportunistic environmental pathogen. It causes fatal 
respiratory distress and septicemia in CF patients. This is termed as 'cepacia syndrome'.

questions.question: Question 2: Which of the following organisms causes scombroid fish poisoning?
questions.explanation:
Scombroid fish poisoning is associated with Pseudomonas aeruginosa. It follows the consumption of both scombroid (mackerel-like) fish and nonscombroid fish that 
have not been refrigerated properly. The musculature of these dark- or red-fleshed fish undergoes 
decomposition by Morganella morganii, Escherichia coli, Proteus species, Klebsiella species, and 
Pseudomonas aeruginosa. There is consequent decarboxylation of the amino acid L-histidine to 
form histamine. A second compound is thought to play a causative role in this intoxication because large doses of 
oral histamine do not reproduce the affliction. The toxin or toxins involved are heat stable and are 
not destroyed by cooking or freezing. Symptoms develop within 15–90 min of ingestion. Most cases are mild, with tingling of lips and 
mouth, mild abdominal discomfort, and nausea. The more severe and commonly described 
presentation includes flushing, conjunctival hyperemia, pruritus, urticaria, and 
angioedema. Without treatment, the symptoms generally resolve within 8–12 h.

questions.question:
Question 3: A patient comes to the dermatology OPD complaining of greenish discoloration of her nails. 
You diagnose her with green nail syndrome. Production of which of the following helps 
differentiate the organism implicated here from other members of its genus?
questions.explanation:
Green nail syndrome is caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa. Production of pyocyanin helps 
differentiate it implicated here from other Pseudomonas species. Pseudomonas aeruginosa is the only member of the Pseudomonas species that produces 
pyocyanin which is a bluish-green pigment. Other species of Pseudomonas also produce pigments 
but they cannot produce pyocyanin. Some of the other pigments produced by Pseudomonas 
species including P. aeruginosa are pyoverdin/flourescein (greenish-yellow pigment), pyorubin 
(red pigment) and pyomelanin (brown pigment).

questions.explanation:
The action of exotoxin A of Pseudomonas aeruginosa is similar to that of the diphtheria toxin. Both exotoxin A and diphtheria toxin cause ADP ribosylation of EF-2 and inhibit protein 
synthesis. Exotoxin A is a single-chain polypeptide with A and B fragments. The B fragment binds 
the toxin while the A fragment inactivates EF-2 in the presence of nicotinamide adenine 
dinucleotide (NAD). This leads to the inhibition of polypeptide chain elongation and thus, protein 243 
Sold by @itachibot synthesis.

questions.question:
Question 5: A patient with acute onset fever, cough and hemoptysis is diagnosed to have Whitmore's 
disease. Which of the following organisms causes this condition?
questions.explanation:
Burkholderia pseudomallei causes Whitmore's disease. Melioidosis was first described by Whitmore and Krishnaswami. Whitmore isolated the bacillus, 
and hence, it is known as Whitmore bacillus and melioidosis is called Whitmore's disease. 
Melioidosis is similar in presentation to glanders disease (caused by Burkholderia mallei). 
Humans are infected tby contact with contaminated soil via skin abrasions. Types of melioidosis: • Acute - It causes acute pneumonia with upper lobe infiltrates or severe necrotizing disease. It 
can also mimic tuberculosis with fever, cough, hemoptysis. It may lead to septicemia. • Chronic - It can lead to the development of multiple caseous or suppurative foci, with skin and 
subcutaneous abscesses. These can lead to lymphangitis and lymphadenopathy. It may involve 
bones and other internal organs. The bacillus has a safety-pin appearance on methylene blue staining. Treatment is divided into 
two stages: an intensive 2 week phase of ceftazidime or a carbapenem followed by at least 12 
weeks of oral cotrimoxazole to eradicate the organism and prevent relapse.

questions.question:
Question 6: A horse-groomer was diagnosed with ulcerative tracheobronchitis. Upon enquiry, it was 
discovered that one of his horses had recently died of pneumonia after developing a fever and 
subcutaneous nodules. Which of the following statements is false about the likely causative 
agent?

options.c: It is the causative agent for Glanders disease.
options.d: It induces Strauss reaction on inoculation into guinea pigs.

questions.explanation:
The development of ulcerative tracheobronchitis after contact with an infected horse is suggestive 
of glanders which is caused by Burkholderia mallei. It is an oxidase variable organism. In this case, the horse likely had glanders, which presents with fever, pneumonia, and 
subcutaneous nodules called Farcy buds. Discharges from the respiratory tract and skin are highly 
infectious and can be transmitted to humans through close contact (occupational route). The 244 
Sold by @itachibot horse-groomer likely contracted the infection by the inhalational route and developed acute 
glanders, which is characterised by fever, mucopurulent nasal discharge and ulcerative necrosis of 
upper respiratory tract (ulcerative tracheobronchitis). It may lead to septicemia and has a high 
fatality rate. Percutaneous exposure causes local suppurative skin lesions with associated regional 
lymphadenopathy. B. mallei is a non-motile Gram-negative bacillus causing Glanders disease. It is an aerobe and a 
facultative anaerobe. It is oxidase variable i.e. it is usually oxidase negative but may occasionally 
show a positive reaction. It is a biosafety level 3 pathogen and so must be handled only in 
specialised laboratories. When male guinea pigs are inoculated intraperitoneally with suspected 
infectious material, it causes Strauss reaction. B. mallei sets up a necrotizing inflammation in the 
scrotal sac within a few days and can be confirmed bacteriologically.

questions.question: Question 7: Which of the following is Burkholderia cepacia resistant to?
questions.explanation:
Burkholderia cepacia is resistant to cefotetan. B. cepacia complex strains are intrinsically resistant to aminoglycosides, polymixin, first and 
second-generation cephalosporins (e.g. cefotetan) and carboxypenicillins. This antimicrobial 
resistance is mediated by efflux pumps, antimicrobial degradation, modifying enzymes or altered 
membrane functions. B. cepacia is a Gram-negative bacillus which can cause severe necrotizing pneumonia in patients 
with chronic granulomatous disease. It can lead to fatal septicemia in patients with cystic fibrosis. Antimicrobial agents that are effective against B. cepacia complex include meropenem, 
ceftazidime, trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, piperacillin and temocillin.

questions.question:
Question 8: An organism cultured in Bordet–Gengou medium shows smooth, refractile, glistening 
colonies resembling 'bisected pearls' or 'mercury drops'. The organism is most likely  
.
questions.explanation:
The organism showing colonies resembling 'bisected pearls' or 'mercury drops' on Bordet-Gengou 
medium most likely is Bordetella pertussis. Bordetella pertussis is a Gram-negative coccobacillus. It causes whooping cough or pertussis in 
children. It can be isolated on the enriched medium Bordet-Genou medium (potato-blood-glycerol agar). 
After incubation for 48 to 72 hours, B. pertussis colonies are small, dome-shaped, smooth, 
opaque, viscid, greyish white, refractile, and glistening resembling 'bisected pearls' or 'mercury 
drops' and are surrounded by a hazy zone of hemolysis. If growth is confluent, an 'aluminium 
paint' appearance is seen. In culture films, Bordetella pertussis bacilli tend to be arranged in loose 
clumps, with clear spaces in between, giving a 'thumbprint' appearance. B. parapertussis (option A) grows on nutrient agar with the production of a brown, diffusible 
pigment after two days. It also grows more rapidly than B.pertussis on charcoal blood agar. 245 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 9: An 8-year-old boy with incomplete vaccination history comes with vomiting after bouts of 
severe, violent cough. What is the mechanism of action of the toxin responsible for this child's 
disease?

options.a: Activation of phospholipase and degrades cell membrane

questions.explanation:
Post-tussive vomiting and bouts of cough in an unimmunized child points to a diagnosis of 
pertussis, caused by Bordetella pertussis. It secretes pertussis toxin (PT), which acts by ADP 
ribosylation and disrupts signal transduction of many cell types. This promotes lymphocytosis. The pertussis toxin disrupts protein synthesis and causes necrosis of parts of the epithelium, 
leading to pseudomembrane formation. Pertussis toxin also promotes sensitization to histamine 
and enhances insulin secretion but these effects have not been demonstrable in patients. They are 
only seen in experimental animals. B. pertussis also produces other toxins like: • Adenylate cyclase toxin (ACT)- It acts by catalysing the production of cAMP by various types of 
cells and inhibiting phagocytosis. • Heat labile toxin (HLT)- It is a cytoplasmic protein present in all bordetellae. It is dermonecrotic 
and lethal in mice. Its pathogenic role is not known. • Tracheal cytotoxin (TCT)- It is low molecular weight peptidoglycan which induces ciliary damage 
in hamster trachea.

questions.question: Question 10: Which of the following statements is false about pertussis toxin?

options.a: It is expressed on the surface of the bacillus.
options.c: "A" portion of A-B structure is the enzymatically active moiety.
options.d: It is similar to cholera toxin in its structure and function.

questions.explanation:
Pertussis toxin (PT) can be toxoided. PT is one of the toxins produced by Bordetella pertussis. It is expressed on the surface of the 
bacillus and secreted into the surrounding medium. It has an A-B structure, the A portion being 
the enzymatically active moiety and B, the binding component. PT is similar to cholera toxin in its 
structure and function. PT has ADP-ribosylating activity and acts on inhibitory Gi  subunit of 
G-protein coupled receptor (GPCR), whereas cholera toxin acts on stimulatory Gs  subunit of 246 
Sold by @itachibot GPCR. Pertussis toxoid is the major component of the acellular pertussis vaccine. A toxoid is a toxin that 
has lost its toxicity but retains its antigenicity.

questions.question:
Question 11: A 4-year-old unimmunized child presents with whooping cough. Which of the following 
constituents of the causative organism is responsible for facilitating its adhesion to the 
respiratory epithelium?
questions.explanation:
Whooping cough is caused by Bordetella pertussis. Filamentous hemagglutinin (FHA) is 
responsible for facilitating the adhesion of Bordetella pertussis to the respiratory epithelium. Bordetella pertussis produces 3 hemagglutinins: Pertussis toxin (PT), lipid factor and FHA. FHA is 
a surface protein and is readily shed. Along with fimbrae, it helps in the adhesion of B. pertussis 
to the cilia of the respiratory epithelium and to erythrocytes. FHA and PT also promote secondary 
infection by coating other bacteria such as Haemophilus influenzae and Pneumococci. They then 
assists their binding to respiratory epithelium. This phenomenon has been termed 'piracy of 
adhesins'.

questions.question: Question 12: What is the incubation period of pertussis in humans?
questions.explanation:
The incubation period of pertussis in humans is 7-14 days. Pertussis is caused by Bordetella pertussis. After the incubation period, the disease takes a 
protracted course comprising three stages: • Catarrhal: It lasts 1-2 weeks and is characterized by coryza, lacrimation, mild cough, low-grade 
fever, and malaise. • Paroxysmal: It lasts 2-4 weeks with the cough becoming more frequent and spasmodic. The 
cough comes in repetitive bursts of 5–10 in number, often within a single expiration. 
Post-tussive vomiting is frequent. The episode may be terminated by an audible whoop, which 
occurs upon rapid inspiration against a closed glottis at the end of a paroxysm. • Convalescent: It lasts 1–3 months and is characterized by gradual resolution of coughing 
episodes. Whooping cough is also known as '100-day cough'. For 6–12 months following the illness, 
intercurrent viral infections may be associated with a recrudescence of paroxysmal cough.

questions.question:
Question 13: You are evaluating a 6-year-old unimmunised girl with cough and abdominal pain. Her 
mother informs you that her daughter has bouts of violent coughing which frequently ends 
with a loud whoop and is accompanied by vomiting. She gives history of similar complaints in 
a classmate 2-3 weeks back. Which of the following drugs will you prescribe for this patient?
questions.explanation:
The given case scenario of whooping cough, post-tussive vomiting, and abdominal pain, along 
with positive history of exposure in an unimmunised child is suggestive of pertussis. 
Erythromycin or one of the newer macrolides such as azithromycin or clarithromycin is the drug 
of choice for the treatment of this condition. Antibiotic therapy in pertussis is used to eradicate the bacteria from the nasopharynx. The 
treatment is beneficial if it is started within 10 days of the disease. Macrolides are the drugs of 247 
Sold by @itachibot choice. Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (Cotrimoxazole) is recommended as an alternative for 
individuals allergic to macrolides. Macrolides may also be used in the chemoprophylaxis of 
pertussis. Post-exposure prophylaxis is given to household close contacts, and high-risk contacts 
(infants, immunocompromised, pregnancy).

questions.question:
Question 14: A young child with unknown immunization history is suspected to have whooping cough. 
Which of the following methods will you prefer to use to collect a specimen for culture?
questions.explanation:
Whooping cough is caused by Bordotella pertussis. The most effective method for collecting a 
specimen for the culture of this organism is the per-nasal or nasopharyngeal swab method. Respiratory specimens may be collected for the culture (gold standard) of Bordetella pertussis by 
three different methods: • Per-nasal swab: A Dacron or rayon tipped swab on a flexible nichrome wire is passed along the 
floor of the nasal cavity and material is collected from the pharyngeal wall. This specimen is 
the most effective and best suited for diagnostic procedures. • Cough plate method: A culture plate is held about 10 to 15 cms in front of the patient's mouth 
during a bout of cough. • Post-nasal (peroral) method: Secretions from the posterior pharyngeal wall are collected with a 
cotton swab on a bent wire passed through the mouth. Other diagnostic tests for pertussis include direct fluorescent aantibody test and PCR on 
nasopharyngeal specimens. Enzyme immunoassays of antibodies after exposure to B. pertussis 
can also be used for patients between 2-4 weeks of illness.

questions.question:
Question 15: 241 
Sold by @itachibot A pregnant woman comes to the ANC clinic for her 2nd dose of the Tdap vaccine. Which of 
the following constitutes the acellular component of this vaccine?
questions.explanation:
Tdap vaccine is the tetanus, diphtheria and acellular pertussis vaccine. The component of the 
acellular pertussis vaccine is inactivated pertussis toxin (PT) and it may contain one or more 
bacterial components such as pertactin, filamentous hemagglutinin, and fimbrial protein. Pertussis vaccine is usually administered in combination with the toxoids of diphtheria and 
tetanus (DTaP). Five doses of pertussis vaccine are recommended - at 2, 4, 6 and 15–18 months of 
age followed by a booster dose at 4–6 years of age. Tdap is now also recommended for pregnant women in between 27 weeks and 36 weeks of 
gestation by the ACOG. This is because infants between the age of 0-2 months are vulnerable to 
pertussis as they do not begin their vaccine schedule before 6 weeks of age. Thus to protect these 
infants, placental transfer of maternal pertussis antibodies has proven to be the most effective 
approach. Children under 4 years who are contacts of patients should receive a booster even if 
they had been previously immunized. Non-immunized contacts should receive full series of 
vaccination and also chemoprophylaxis with erythromycin for 10 days after contact with the 
patient has ceased. 248 
Sold by @itachibot Haemophilus
